p.hi: (Now rapidly dying out of our land).

lg.l: Merry chimer, Merry chimer. The bellbird/korimako, also referred to as the moko-moko by settlers in the nineteenth century, is known for the clear ringing notes of its call. The species is especially common in the South Island. merry chimer,
At early dawn Early dawn. The bellbird’s most distinctive call is heard around dawn, when many of the species are present.
Telling that joys to thee belong,
Alas! we now but seldom hear
For thou seem’st doomed to disappear,
It steals the honey from the tree,
And it leaves thee naught. Naught. Settlers had debated since at least the 1860s that the introduction of bees was providing competition for nectar-eating indigenous species such as the bellbird.
But as the old we love the new;
Thy purple throat and olive hue: Purple throat and olive hue. The male bellbird is olive green, with a purple-tinted head.

Yet we wish in vain. Vain. The bellbird was listed a few years later as a protected species under the 1886 amendment to the Animal Protection Act (1880), which allowed for the Governor “to prohibit absolutely or for such time as he may think fit the destruction of any bird indigenous to the colony.”
Thy doom is fixed by Nature’s law;
We’ll miss thy voice from leafy shaw, Shaw. A small wood or grove.
Why should we ever know new joys,
